metadata.case_name: K.S. Rashid & Son v. Income Tax Investigation Commission

facts.text: Partnership firm K.S. Rashid & Son started on 5th May 1934 with partners K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed, and Mrs. Zafar Muhammed.
Mrs. Zafar Muhammed died on 7th January 1946, resulting in dissolution of the original partnership.
New firm bearing same name started on 8th January 1946 with surviving partners K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed, and Saeeda Begum as third partner.
Income-tax assessments completed up to 31st March 1943 in all cases.
Central Government referred cases of the firm and individuals to Income-tax Investigation Commission under section 5 of Act XXX of 1947 on 31st December 1947.
Authorised official under section 5(4)(3) of the Act started investigations extending beyond 31st March 1943.
Petition complaining about extension of investigations made to authorised official on 8th April 1949; no order passed as Commission expected change of law.
Law amended by Ordinance dated 5th July 1949.
Account books shown to official under protest.

Three applications filed before Commission on 17th September 1949: (1) no investigation re Mrs. Zafar Muhammed as dead; (2) no jurisdiction over Saeeda Begum as new partner not previously assessed; (3) no enquiry into new firm from 8th Jan 1946.

Four miscellaneous petitions (C.M. Nos. 256, 260, 261, 262 of 1950; also mentioned as 259-262) filed before High Court of Punjab in June 1950 seeking writ of prohibition, certiorari, or revision under arts 226/227.
Rules issued by High Court on 25th July 1950 after report from Commission.
High Court dismissed petitions on 10th August 1950 on grounds of lack of jurisdiction and exclusive remedy under the Act.
Certificate granted by High Court under art 133(1)(c); appeals to Supreme Court.
Appellants availed remedy under s.8(5) of Act; reference made to High Court of Allahabad awaiting decision.
Petitioners are assessees belonging to U.P.; assessments by Income-tax Commissioner of that State; subsequent proceedings by U.P. authorities; case stated to Allahabad High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Punjab High Court had jurisdiction under arts 226/227 to issue writs of certiorari or prohibition against Income-tax Investigation Commission located in Delhi regarding U.P. assessees.
Whether remedy under s.8(5) of Act XXX of 1947 is exclusive, excluding art 226/227 jurisdiction.
Whether authorised official could extend investigations beyond 31st March 1943; applicability to dead partner, new partner, new firm.

petitioner_arguments.text: Authorised official extended investigations contrary to Act beyond 31st March 1943 up to which assessments completed.
No investigation re Mrs. Zafar Muhammed as dead; no jurisdiction over Saeeda Begum as new unassessed partner; no enquiry into new firm post 8th Jan 1946.
Punjab High Court has jurisdiction under art 226 as Commission in Delhi within its territories.
Art 226 available despite special Act remedies.

respondent_arguments.text: No jurisdiction in Punjab High Court as assessees in U.P., assessments by U.P. officers, references to Allahabad HC; mere location of Commission in Delhi insufficient.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi

respondent_arguments.text: Special Act provides exclusive remedies; arts 226/227 not available.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.8(5) Act XXX 1947; ss.66,66A Income-tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Court cannot give relief due to ss.5(3) and 9 of Act XXX 1947.

court_reasoning.text: Punjab High Court has jurisdiction under art 226 as Commission within territories amenable to jurisdiction; distinguishes Parlakimedi as pre-Constitution limited prerogative writs; Constitution art 226 confers wide powers throughout territories.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art 226 powers not limited like pre-Constitution; location of authority sufficient if within territories.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide if s.8(5) exclusive; art 226 discretionary, refuse if adequate alternative remedy available; appellants already availed s.8(5) reference to Allahabad HC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discretionary jurisdiction not to be invoked when alternative remedy pursued.

holdings.text: High Courts have jurisdiction under art 226 to issue writs to authorities within their territories, regardless of subject-matter location.
Art 226 remedy discretionary; not granted if adequate alternative under statute already pursued.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi
precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-Constitution limits on prerogative writs; mere location insufficient in that context, but not applicable post-Constitution art 226.
Explains wide art 226 jurisdiction post-Constitution; distinguishes Parlakimedi.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nundo Lal Bose v. The Calcutta Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari issued based on location; contrasted in Parlakimedi.

precedents_cited.case_name: Besant v. The Advocate General of Madras

statutes_cited.name: Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947 (Act XXX of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs investigations; provides reference remedy to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ jurisdiction and appeals; wide powers under 226.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied mutatis mutandis to references under s.8(5) of 1947 Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held Punjab High Court has jurisdiction under art 226 but refused to interfere as appellants had availed alternative remedy under s.8(5) of Act XXX 1947 with reference pending in Allahabad High Court; appeals dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The Constitution introduced a fundamental change of law in this respect. Article 226 confers on all the High Courts new and very wide powers in the matter of issuing writs which they never possessed before.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains expansion of writ jurisdiction post-Constitution.

key_quotes.text: The remedy provided for in article 226 of the Constitution is a discretionary remedy and the High Court has always the discretion to refuse to grant any writ if it is satisfied that the aggrieved party can have an adequate or suitable relief elsewhere.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for refusing relief due to alternative remedy.

key_quotes.text: The question of jurisdiction must be regarded as one of substance.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Parlakimedi, but reinterpreted in constitutional context.
